sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving gases
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the following reaction at 298 K:
2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2SO₃(g)
given the following standard enthalpy of formation values:
ΔH°f (SO₂(g)) = -296.8 kJ/mol
ΔH°f (O₂(g)) = 0 kJ/mol
ΔH°f (SO₃(g)) = -395.7 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH° = Σ ΔH°f (products) - Σ ΔH°f (reactants)

For the given reaction:

2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2SO₃(g)

The enthalpy change (ΔH°) can be calculated as follows:

ΔH° = [2 × ΔH°f (SO₃(g))] - [2 × ΔH°f (SO₂(g)) + ΔH°f (O₂(g))]

Substitute the given values:

ΔH° = [2 × (-395.7 kJ/mol)] - [2 × (-296.8 kJ/mol) + 0 kJ/mol]

ΔH° = (-791.4 kJ) - (-593.6 kJ)

ΔH° = -197.8 kJ

The standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the reaction is -197.8 kJ.
